In this master, we study the bandwidth related metrics measurement methods and techniques. We evaluate their accuracy in heterogeneous, wired and wireless environments (WLAN-LAN, WLAN-WAN and Ad hoc networks). Methods using the one-packet model have difficulties in measuring path capacity when it has wireless links. We investigate the source of their errors, and show that the presence of Layer-2 (L2) store-and-forward devices, such as Ethernet switches or Wireless Access Points, have a detrimental effect on the accuracy of Pathchar like’s tools. Specifically, each L2 store-and forward device introduces an additional serialization latency in a packet’s delay, which results in consistent underestimation of that L3 hop’s capacity. The packet train technique estimates also the path Available Bandwidth from the dispersion. In this master, we choose the passive measurement analysis approach based on Cisco’s NetFlow Data Export service to validate the comparison between “Pathload” and “Cprobe” accuracy and response time, when acting in an heterogeneous WLAN-WAN private network environment. Finally, as available bandwidth is a dynamic metric, it could be measured in ad hoc network when the route is stable. We evaluate, by simulation, “Pathload” tool methodology and investigate its limits in such environments using two routing protocols AODV and DSDV.
